revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Artist Discography | Artist = [[Britney Spears]] video | Image = Femme Fatale Vancouver 5.jpg | Image size = 250px | Caption = Spears performing during the [[Femme Fatale Tour]] in July 2011 | Music videos = 37 | MV link = Music videos | Option = 2 | Option name = Concert tour videos | Option link = Concert tour videos | Option color = gold | 1Option = 4 | 1Option name = Video compilations | 1Option link = Music video compilations | 1Option color = #87CEFA | 2Option = 0 | 2Option name = Video singles | 2Option link = Video singles | 2Option color = #C0C0C0 | References = Yes | Ref link = Notes }}
The videography of American recording artist [[Britney Spears]] consists of thirty-two [[music videos]], four [[home video]]s, two [[concert|concert tour videos]], one [[compilation album|music video compilation]], and two [[documentary|documentaries]]. In 1997 Spears signed a recording contract with [[Jive Records]]. Spears' first music video "[[...Baby One More Time (song)|...Baby One More Time]]", in which she chose to dress as a Catholic schoolgirl, propelled her to superstardom.<ref name="Hughes 2005 147">{{harvnb|Hughes|2005|p=147}}</ref> It ranked number one on [[Total Request Live|TRL's]] Final Countdown of the most iconic music videos.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2008/11/review-trls-tot.html | work=[[Los Angeles Times]]| publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|title=Show Tracker|first=Robert|last=Lloyd| date=2008-11-17}}</ref> The music video for the lead single from Spears' second album, "[[Oops!... I Did It Again (song)|Oops!... I Did It Again]]", was similarly successful. Set on [[Mars]], Spears dons a tight-fitting red [[jumpsuit]]. The "[[Stronger (Britney Spears song)|Stronger]]" music video had a more sophisticated, adult feel to it.<ref name="stronger">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1626492/20091117/spears_britney.jhtml|title=How Britney Spears' 'Stronger' Video Made Her A Diva |date=2009-10-18|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|accessdate=2009-10-19}}</ref> 2001's "[[I'm a Slave 4 U]]" let Spears move further into a more mature territory, performing a complicated dance routine in a risquÃ© outfit.<ref name="slave">{{cite web | author=D'Angelo, Joe | title=Britney Works Double-Time On Music Videos | date=September 20, 2001 | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1449019/20010920/spears_britney.jhtml | work=[[MTV News]] | publisher=MTV | accessdate=2009-01-03}}</ref>
"[[Me Against the Music]]", which featured [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], was released in 2003. Director [[Paul Hunter]] talked to [[MTV News]] about the video, saying, "Madonna is an icon of an earlier generation, and then Britney of the newer generation. [...] I wanted it to be a bit of a [[cat and mouse|cat-and-mouse]] sort of game and a little bit of a foreplay between Britney and Madonna and just sort of tease the audience."<ref name="matm">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1626705/20091119/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Spears And Madonna 'Tease' Fans In 'Me Against The Music' Video |date=2009-12-20|accessdate=2010-09-22|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV}}</ref> Spears came up with the storyline for "[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]", directed by [[Joseph Kahn]].<ref name="toxic">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1490554/20040825/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Yes, Britney Really Is Naked In The 'Toxic' Video|date=2004-08-25|accessdate=2010-08-22|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV}}</ref> Spears plays three different incarnations of herself and poisons her unfaithful lover. Throughout the video, there are scenes of Spears naked covered in diamonds.<ref name="toxic"/> The music video for "[[Everytime]]", directed by famed photographer [[David LaChapelle]], was notably darker than Spears' previous videos.<ref name="everytime">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1486294/20040409/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Says Controversial New Video Is About Reincarnation|date=2004-04-12|accessdate=2010-04-28|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|work=[[MTV News]] | publisher=MTV}}</ref> The video portrays Spears as a star hounded by paparazzi, who drowns in her bathtub when she starts bleeding from a wound in her head. In the hospital, doctors fail to resuscitate her while a child is born in the next room, implying she has been reincarnated. The original treatment would have had Spears killing herself from a drug overdose, but the plot was removed after it received criticism by several organizations, who perceived it as a glamorization of suicide. Featuring many religious references, the music video was noted by contemporary critics for predicting Spears's future struggles with fame.<ref name="fox">{{harvnb|Fox|2009|p=47}}</ref><ref name="bestmtv">{{cite web|last=Montgomery|first=James |title=Is Britney Spears' 'If U Seek Amy' Her Best Video Ever? |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1606882/20090312/spears_britney.jhtml | work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV| date=2009-03-12 | accessdate=2009-12-01}}</ref><ref name="everytimerstone">{{cite journal|url=|title=The Complete Video Guide: "Everytime"|year=2009|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=Jann Wenner|accessdate=2010-03-13|issn=0035-791X}}</ref> The clip for Spears' cover of "[[My Prerogative]]" was described the video as "[having] an element of old Hollywood glamour and mystery".<ref name="prerogative">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1490551/20040825/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney To Marry Kevin Federline In 'My Prerogative' Video|date=2004-08-25|accessdate=2010-03-19| last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV}}</ref> The video begins with Spears driving erratically in a [[Porsche]] and crashing it into a pool.<ref name="prerogative2">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1490312/20040817/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Makes Party-Crashing Her Prerogative In Next Video|date=2004-08-17|accessdate=2010-03-19| last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=MTV}}</ref>
The music video for Spears' 2007 comeback single "[[Gimme More]]" displayed Spears as a [[stripper]] and featured a break from Spears's highly choreographed music videos.<ref name="gimme">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/13/arts/music/13brit.html/?_r=1|title=Spearsâs Awards Fiasco Stirs Speculation About Her Future |date=2007-09-13|accessdate=2010-02-23|last=Leeds|first=Jeff|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}}</ref> It received mixed to negative reviews from critics, who panned Spears's pole dancing as well as the lack of storyline.<ref name="gimme2">{{cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2007/10/05/britney-video-g/|title=Snap judgment: Britney Spears' 'Gimme More' video|date=2007-10-05|accessdate=2010-02-23|last=Slezak|first=Michael|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Warner]]}}</ref><ref name=metro>{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/68938-britneys-new-lap-dancing-video|title=Britney's new lap dancing video!|date=2007-10-05|accessdate=2010-02-23|last=Harmsworth|first=Andrei|work=[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers Ltd]]}}</ref> "[[Piece of Me]]" referenced Spears' life at the time, while "[[Break the Ice (Britney Spears song)|Break the Ice]]" was accompanied by an [[animation|animated]] music video showing Spears as a [[superhero]]ine. 2008's "[[Womanizer (song)|Womanizer]]" was seen as a return to form for Spears.<ref name=10tensongs>{{cite news|url=http://top40.about.com/od/britneyspears/tp/topbritneyspearssongs.htm|title= Top 10 Britney Spears Songs|year=2009|accessdate=2010-04-18|last=Lamb|first=Bill|work=[[About.com]] | publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]}}</ref><ref name=ew>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20233555,00.html|title=Britney Has a Sexy New Video. Soâ¦Was it Worth the Wait?|date=2008-10-17|accessdate=2010-01-10|last=Watson|first=Margeaux|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Warner]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=|title=Spearsâ "Womanizer" Video Premieres: Is Britney Back For Real?|date=2008-10-11|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=Jann Wenner|accessdate=2010-01-10|issn=0035-791X}}</ref> Described as a sequel to "Toxic", the concept was again pitched to director Kahn by Spears.<ref name="womanizer">{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1626947/20091123/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Spears' 'Womanizer' Clip Proved She Still Had It|date=2009-11-24|accessdate=2010-01-10|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|last2=Elias|first2=Matt|publisher=MTV|work=[[MTV News]]}}</ref> The video for "[[Circus (song)|Circus]]" portrayed Spears as the ringmaster of a circus accompanied by different performers, and it is interspersed with scenes of Spears in different circus settings. "[[If U Seek Amy]]" saw Spears at a sex party that takes place at her house, before she transforms into a typical American housewife,<ref name="bestmtv"/> while "[[Radar (song)|Radar]]" pays tribute to Madonna's "[[Take a Bow (Madonna song)|Take a Bow]]".<ref name="radar">{{cite web | author=Jocelyn Vena |title= Britney Spears Channeled 'Classy' Madonna In 'Radar' Video |publisher=MTV|work=[[MTV News]]| date=2009-11-25 | url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1627052/20091124/story.jhtml | accessdate=2009-11-26}}</ref> The clip for "[[3 (song)|3]]" was described as "simple" and "very, very minimal."<ref name="3video">{{cite web|url=http://www.lifeandstylemag.com/2009/10/britney-spears-3-video.html|title=Life & Style exclusive: Britney's video director speaks|date=2009-10-20|work=[[Life & Style (magazine)|Life & Style]]|publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]]|accessdate=2010-01-04}}</ref>
Spears ranked #4 VH1's "50 Greatest Women of the Video Era" show list, ahead of most of her contemporaries and behind only veterans like Madonna, [[Janet Jackson]], and [[Whitney Houston]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/photos/gallery/?thumbnails=true&fid=1477005|title=The Greatest: 50 Greatest Women of the Video Era |accessdate=2009-12-17|work=[[VH1]] |publisher=[[MTV Networks]]}}</ref>
==Music videos== {| class="wikitable" |- ! width=10 | Year ! width=300 | Title ! width=200 | Album ! width=225 | Director |- || 1998 || "[[...Baby One More Time (single)|...Baby One More Time]]" || rowspan=5 | ''[[...Baby One More Time (album)|...Baby One More Time]]'' || rowspan=3 | [[Nigel Dick]] |- | rowspan=4 | 1999 || "[[Sometimes (Britney Spears song)|Sometimes]]" |- | "[[(You Drive Me) Crazy]]" <small>(The Stop Remix!)</small> |- | "[[Born to Make You Happy]]" || [[Bille Woodruff]] |- | "[[From the Bottom of My Broken Heart]]" || [[Gregory Dark]] |- | rowspan=3 | 2000 || "[[Oops!... I Did It Again (song)|Oops!... I Did It Again]]" || rowspan=4 | ''[[Oops!... I Did It Again]]'' || Nigel Dick |- | "[[Lucky (Britney Spears song)|Lucky]]" || [[Dave Meyers (director)|Dave Meyers]] |- | "[[Stronger (Britney Spears song)|Stronger]]" || [[Joseph Kahn]] |- | rowspan=3 | 2001 || "[[Don't Let Me Be the Last to Know]]" || [[Herb Ritts]] |- | "[[I'm a Slave 4 U]]" || rowspan=8 | ''[[Britney (album)|Britney]]'' || [[Francis Lawrence]] |- | "[[Overprotected]]" || Bille Woodruff |- | rowspan=5 | 2002|| "[[I'm Not a Girl, Not Yet a Woman]]" <sup>1</sup> || [[Wayne Isham]] |- | "[[Overprotected#Darkchild Remix video|Overprotected]]" <small>(Darkchild Remix)</small> ||rowspan=2| [[Chris Applebaum]] |- | "[[I Love Rock 'n' Roll|I Love Rock 'N Roll]]" |- | "[[Anticipating]]" <sup>2</sup>|| [[Marty Callner]] |- | "[[Boys_(Britney_Spears_song)|Boys]]" <small>(ft. [[Pharrell Williams]])</small> || Dave Meyers |- | rowspan=2 | 2003 || "[[That's Where You Take Me]]" <sup>3</sup> || [[Marty Callner]] |- | "[[Me Against the Music]]" || rowspan=4 | ''[[In the Zone]]'' || [[Paul Hunter (director)|Paul Hunter]] |- | rowspan=5 | 2004 || "[[Toxic (song)|Toxic]]" || Joseph Kahn |- | "[[Everytime]]" || [[David LaChapelle]] |- | "[[Outrageous]]" <sup>4</sup> || Dave Meyers |- | "[[My Prerogative#Britney Spears|My Prerogative]]" || rowspan=3 | ''[[Greatest Hits: My Prerogative]]'' || [[Jake Nava]] |- | "[[Chris Cox Megamix]]" <sup>5</sup> || Various directors |- | rowspan=2 | 2005 || "[[Do Somethin']]" || Britney Spears, Bille Woodruff |- | "[[Someday (I Will Understand)]]" || ''[[Mona Lisa (Britney Spears song)|Britney & Kevin: Chaotic]]'' || [[Michael Haussman]] |- | rowspan=2 | 2007 || "[[Gimme More]]" <sup>6</sup> || rowspan=3 | ''[[Blackout (Britney Spears album)|Blackout]]'' || Britney Spears, Jake Sarfaty |- | "[[Piece of Me]]" <sup>7</sup> || Wayne Isham |- | rowspan=3 | 2008 || "[[Break the Ice (Britney Spears song)|Break the Ice]]" <sup>8</sup> || [[Robert Hales (director)|Robert Hales]] |- | "[[Womanizer (song)|Womanizer]]" || rowspan=4 | ''[[Circus (Britney Spears album)|Circus]]'' || Joseph Kahn |- | "[[Circus (song)|Circus]]" || Francis Lawrence |- | rowspan=3 | 2009 || "[[If U Seek Amy]]" || Jake Nava |- | "[[Radar (song)|Radar]]" || Dave Meyers |- | "[[3 (song)|3]]" <sup>9</sup> ||| ''[[The Singles Collection (Britney Spears album)|The Singles Collection]]'' || [[Diane Martel]] |- | rowspan=4 | 2011 || "[[Hold It Against Me]]" || rowspan=4 | ''[[Femme Fatale (Britney Spears album)|Femme Fatale]]'' || [[Jonas Ã kerlund]] |- | "[[Till The World Ends]]" <sup>10</sup> || [[Ray Kay]] |- | "[[I Wanna Go]]" || rowspan=2|Chris Marrs Piliero |- | "[[Criminal (Britney Spears song)|Criminal]]" |} '''Footnotes:''' *<sup>1</sup> There are two versions of "I'm Not a Girl, Not Yet a Woman". One of them is the original video, while the other contains clips from the movie ''[[Crossroads (2002 film)|Crossroads]]''. *<sup>2</sup> "[[Anticipating]]" (2002) â Spears' first live music video, taken from her ''[[Dream Within a Dream Tour]]'' performance directed by [[Marty Callner]] and was released in France and Brazil only. It also had some airplay in the [[Philippines]] and [[Taiwan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LlU1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=fCUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=508,2422565|title=Teendom's New Music|last=Sablan|first=Mark M.|date=2003-02-05|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> *<sup>3</sup> "That's Where You Take Me" (2003) â The video is made from ''[[Live from Las Vegas (Britney Spears DVD)|Live from Las Vegas]]'' footage of backstage and live performances for a special release in the [[Philippines]] and was directed by [[Marty Callner]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.discogs.com/Britney-Spears-Thats-Where-You-Take-Me/release/1961865|title=That's Where You Take Me|work=Discogs|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> *<sup>4</sup> The video for "Outrageous" is unfinished. It's a montage of scenes before Spears injured her knee. *<sup>5</sup> The music video for the Chris Cox Megamix is for the radio edit. The only music videos that are not shown are "Born to Make You Happy" and "My Prerogative". *<sup>6</sup> The video for "Gimme More" contains two different versions with two different endings. In the uncensored version, Spears is topless. On July 19 2011, a new version of the video featuring never before scenes leaked. *<sup>7</sup> There are two versions of "Piece of Me". The international version shows Spears in the first verse singing in front of a background of flashes, wearing a dress and a blond bob wig, while the US version shows her singing in front of a colourful background, which can also be seen in other parts of the international video. *<sup>8</sup> The music video for "Break The Ice" is made in an anime style. *<sup>9</sup> There are two versions of "3". The first one is the official music video, and the other one is the director's cut, which shows new scenes, different sequences and has no music at the beginning.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://perezhilton.com/2009-12-15-even-better-than-the-original-2|title=Even Better Than The Original!|work=[[Perez Hilton]]|accessdate=2010-04-10}}</ref> *<sup>10</sup> There are two versions of "Till The World Ends". The first one is the directors cut which shows the apocalypse theme in the video while the second one is a choreography cut which shows only dance sequences in the video.
==Miscellaneous videos==
* "When Your Eyes Say It" (2001) â It was planned as the fourth or fifth single from ''[[Oops!... I Did It Again]]'', but was unreleased due to unknown reasons. It was shot in January 2001 by [[Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris]].<ref>{{cite web | title=MvdBase | url=http://www.mvdbase.com/video.php?id=26171 | accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "[[What's Going On (song)#Artists Against AIDS Worldwide cover|What's Going On]]" (2001) â Music video to promote the All-Star Tribute [[charity single]]. It features various singers.<ref>{{cite web | title=hopeforafricanchildren |work=Artists Against AIDS Worldwide's New Superstar Version of Marvin Gaye's 'What's Going On' in Stores Tuesday, October 30 | url=http://www.hopeforafricanchildren.org/New/Press/pr_103001.html | accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "Overprotected" (2002) - ''[[Crossroads (2002 film)|Crossroads]]'' promotional version of the video, features outtakes from the movie. It is included at the end credits of the movie and in the official video release ''[[Britney: The Videos]]'', and also as an enhanced section from [[Britney (album)|Britney]].<ref>{{cite web | title=Mixup Music Store | work= "The Videos" | url=http://www.mixup.com.mx/mixup/Product.aspx?sku=828765404792 | accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "[[Anticipating]]" (2002) â Spears' first live music video, taken from her ''[[Dream Within a Dream Tour]]'' performance directed by [[Marty Callner]] and was released in France and Brazil only. It also had some airplay in the [[Philippines]] and [[Taiwan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LlU1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=fCUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=508,2422565|title=Teendom's New Music|last=Sablan|first=Mark M.|date=2003-02-05|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "That's Where You Take Me" (2003) â The video is made from ''[[Live from Las Vegas (Britney Spears DVD)|Live from Las Vegas]]'' footage of backstage and live performances for a special release in the [[Philippines]] and was directed by [[Marty Callner]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.discogs.com/Britney-Spears-Thats-Where-You-Take-Me/release/1961865|title=That's Where You Take Me|work=Discogs|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "Gimme More" (2007) â Spears' original video had a complete different concept and contained scenes wearing a funeral outfit as well as different outfits while dancing around the pole and its theme was [[reincarnation|rebirth]]. This version of the video was leaked on July 19 2011, which featured new scenes and different shots of Spears' dancing around the pole.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20143046,00.html|title=New Britney Video Set to Air|work=People|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "[[When I Grow Up (Pussycat Dolls song)|When I Grow Up]]" (2008) - Spears made a cameo appearance in this video, but her scenes were cut for unknown reasons. * "[[Human Nature (Madonna song)|Human Nature]]" (2008) â Madonna ''[[Sticky & Sweet Tour]]'' backdrop video of Britney Spears trapped in an elevator. It also adds the line 'It's Britney, bitch' at the end of the song.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/2008-10-05-3494094949_x.htm|title=Madonna gives fans a treat with "Sticky & Sweet"|work=UsaToday|accessdate=2010-04-09 | date=2008-10-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/arts/2008/1108/madonna.html|title=Britney appears on stage with Madonna|work=RTE|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "[[Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This) (song)#Marilyn Manson cover|Everybodyâs Looking For Somethin']]" (2009) â Made as an interlude to ''[[The Circus Starring Britney Spears]]''. It features Spears at a party while singing along to [[Marilyn Manson]]'s cover of "Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)".<ref name="setlist.fm">{{cite news|url=http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/britney-spears/2009/burswood-dome-perth-australia-4bd7c356.html|title=Britney Spears Concert at Burswood Dome, Perth, Australia Setlist on November 6, 2009|work=Setlist.com|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/03/12/britney-spears-circus-spectacle-draws-madonna-to-new-york-show-full-report/|title=Britney Spearsâ "Circus" Spectacle Draws Madonna to New York Show: Full Report|work=RollingStone|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "Break the Ice" (2009) â Made as an interlude to ''The Circus Starring Britney Spears''. It is a collage of almost every music video from 1999 to 2008.<ref name="setlist.fm"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.celebuzz.com/britneys-circus-set-list-revealed-s90101/|title=Britney's Circus Set List Revealed!|work=Celebuzz|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref> * "Kill the Lights" (2009) â Animated video, based on the story winner of a Fan Fiction Contest at Britney.com. It shows paparazzi following Spears to another planet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.britney.com/au/node/76813|title=WORLD PREMIERE: "Kill The Lights" Animated Video|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.britneyspears.com/2009/09/buy-the-kill-the-lights-fan-video-on-itunes.php|title=Buy the 'Kill the Lights' Fan Video on iTunes|accessdate=2010-04-09}}</ref>
==Video albums== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:14em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:16em;"| Album details ! scope="col" style="width:12em;"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Time Out with Britney Spears]]'' | *Released: December 21, 1999 *Label: [[Jive Records|Jive]] *Formats: [[DVD]], [[VHS]] | *US: 3Ã Platinum<ref name="riaa">[http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=Britney%20Spears&format=VIDEO%20LONGFORM&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25 RIAA certification searchable database - "Britney Spears"]. [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. Retrieved January 28, 2008</ref> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Live and More!]]'' | *Released: November 21, 2000 *Label: Jive *Formats: DVD, VHS | *US: 3Ã Platinum<ref name="riaa"/> *FR: Platinum</small> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Britney: The Videos]]'' | *Released: November 20, 2001 *Label: Jive *Format: DVD | *US: 2Ã Platinum<ref name="riaa"/> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Live from Las Vegas (video)|Live from Las Vegas]]'' | *Released: February 12, 2002 *Label: Jive *Format: DVD | *US: 2Ã Platinum<ref name="riaa"/> *AUS: Platinum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ariacharts.com.au/pages/charts_display_music.asp?chart=1V40DVD |title=Top 40 DVD Chart - Australian Record Industry Assocation |publisher=Ariacharts.com.au |date= |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[In the Zone (video)|In the Zone]]'' | *Released: April 6, 2004 *Label: Jive *Format: CD/DVD | *US: Platinum<ref name="riaa"/> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Greatest Hits: My Prerogative (video)|Greatest Hits: My Prerogative]]'' | *Released: November 9, 2004 *Label: Jive *Format: DVD | *US: 2Ã Platinum<ref name="riaa"/> *AUS: 3Ã Platinum<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupageshttpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2008DVD_000.htm |title=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2008DVD.htm |publisher=Aria.com.au |date=2008-12-31 |accessdate=2011-09-17}}</ref> |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Britney & Kevin: Chaotic (video)|Britney & Kevin: Chaotic]]'' | *Released: September 27, 2005 *Label: Jive *Format: CD/DVD | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Britney: For the Record]]'' | *Released: April 7, 2009 *Label: Jive *Format: DVD | |- ! scope="row" | ''[[Britney Spears Live: The Femme Fatale Tour]]'' | *Released: November 21, 2011 *Label: [[RCA Records|RCA]] *Format: [[Blu-ray]], CD/DVD | |}
==MTV Awards== ====MTV Video Music Awards==== The [[MTV Video Music Awards]] were established in 1984 by [[MTV]] to celebrate the top [[music videos]] of the year. {{awards table}} |- |rowspan=4|1999 |rowspan=4|"[[...Baby One More Time]]" |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Female Video|Best Female Video]] |{{nom}} |- |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Pop Video|Best Pop Video]] |{{nom}} |- |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Choreography|Best Choreography in a Video]] |{{nom}} |- |International Viewer's Choice Awards Russia |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=4|2000 |"[[(You Drive Me) Crazy]]" |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Dance Video|Best Dance Video]] |{{nom}} |- |rowspan=3|"[[Oops!... I Did It Again]]" |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Female Video|Best Female Video]] |{{nom}} |- |[[MTV Video Music Award for Best Pop Video|Best Pop Video]] |{{nom}} |- |[[MTV Video Music Award -
